question: Question_B_01_(b)
statement:
Let $L$ be the line $3x = 4y$.

Find the matrix \emph{A} which represents $\text{Ref}_{L}$, the
reflection across the line \emph{L}.
sols:
We can alternatively consider what a reflection does to vectors.

Any vector pointing along the line 3x=4y, \textless{}4,3\textgreater{},
for example, will be reflected onto itself.

Any vector perpendicular to \textless{}4,3\textgreater{} will point in
the completely opposite direction after reflection. For example,
\textless{}-3,4\textgreater{} will become \textless{}3,-4\textgreater{}.

Note that these two vectors are linearly independent. Thus if A denotes
the reflection,
$A \begin{bmatrix} 4 \\ 3 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 4 \\ 3 \end{bmatrix}$
and
$A \begin{bmatrix} -3 \\ 4 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 3 \\ -4 \end{bmatrix}$,
which we can write as a matrix equation

\begin{align*}A \begin{bmatrix} 4 & -3 \\ 3 & 4 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 4 & 3 \\ 3 & -4 \end{bmatrix}.\end{align*}

Thus
$A = \begin{bmatrix} 4 & 3 \\ 3 & -4 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 4 & -3 \\ 3 & 4 \end{bmatrix}^{-1} = \begin{bmatrix} 7/25 & 24/25 \\ 24/25 & -7/25 \end{bmatrix}.$
hints:
To reflect a vector about a line that goes through the origin, let
$v = (v_x, v_y)$ be a vector in the direction of the line. The matrix
which represents $\text{Ref}_{L}$ is given by

\begin{align*}\mathbf{A} = \frac{1}{\lVert v\rVert^2} \begin{bmatrix} v_x^2 - v_y^2 & 2 v_x v_y \\ 2 v_x v_y & v_y^2 - v_x^2 \end{bmatrix}\end{align*}
